Graphical abstract In this contribution, we report the successful utilization of several zinc complexes based on the N4–N,N-bis(2-pyridinecarboxamide)-1,2-benzene chelating ligand (and some of its variations) as catalysts in the coupling of epoxides with carbon dioxide to afford cyclic carbonates in good yields. The complexes were tested with cyclohexene oxide and propylene oxide. A broader catalytic screening involving several commercial available epoxides was also carried out with a selected catalyst. Keywords Zinc complexes Epoxide Carbon dioxide Cyclic carbonate Homogeneous catalysis 1 Introduction Raising the level of sustainability of numerous syntheses and processes and using cleverly renewable resources come to the fore in different sectors of the modern chemistry. Particularly if one bears in mind the fact, that maintaining a vast, affordable portfolio of crude-oil-based products will become increasingly difficult within the coming century. One actual renewable resource of major interest is carbon dioxide. Carbon dioxide is abundant, easy-to-handle, non-toxic if used sensibly and is, as soon as the problem of its thermodynamic stability is solved, an attractive raw material for organic syntheses [1]. The coupling of epoxides, reactive products per se, with carbon dioxide yields aliphatic polycarbonates and cyclic carbonates, the latter being the thermodynamic products (Scheme 1 ). This reaction is in the direct focus of academics as well as industry primarily due to a promising range of industrial applications [2]. Aliphatic polycarbonates, which are generated along this synthesis route, are a welcome extension to the conventional aromatic polycarbonates because of, amongst others, a higher intrinsic biodegradability [3] (e.g., polypropylene carbonate). On the other side, cyclic carbonates are industrially utilized as electrolytes in Li-ions cells, as polar, non-toxic solvents in cleaning processes or as substrates for the synthesis of polymers and high value-added molecules [4]. Since the first catalytic system for the copolymerization of CO2 with epoxides released by Inoue et al. [5], a wide range of heterogeneous or homogeneous catalytic systems has been reported and many reviews try to keep pace with the development of new systems in this area [6–8]. Considering a homogeneous catalysis, it boils down to the fact that three complementary features are necessary for a successful coupling of an epoxide with CO2: an acidic metal centre capable to coordinate the epoxide, a chelating ligand with appropriate geometry and a leaving group able to easily form a reactive metalalkoxide bond. Exclusively this bond is able to interact easily with CO2 and to keep the activation-insertion steps running. Accordingly a wide range of metal/leaving group/ligand configurations has been investigated and published in the recent years, catalysts involving zinc [9], aluminum [10] and cobalt [11] being presently the most promising candidates. On the ligand side, the most performing architectures are based on tetra-arylporphyrins (N4) [12], Schiff bases (N4) [13], salens/salphens and related ligands (N2O2) [14], substituted phenols (N2O) [15] or complex bridged bisphenols (N4O2) [16]. To reach a wide acceptance, a catalyst requires, on the operative side, a high activity and versatility combined with an easy separation from the products and, on the sustainability side, a low toxicity and an economical synthetic route. Matching all these prerequisites is not easy and explains why the search for new catalytic systems in this area resembles a never-ending quest. We investigated in earlier studies the role of ionic cobalt-, iron- and chromium-complexes involving the N4-bpb ligand system in the coupling of epoxides with CO2 (bpb: N,N-bis-(2-pyridine-carboxamide)-1,2-benzene) [17] Considering the good performance of the cobalt catalysts in the formation of cyclic carbonates and aliphatic poly(cyclohexenecarbonate), we decided to expand this class of complex to include zinc compounds addressing so the toxicity issue connected to the use of cobalt [18]. We report in this contribution, the effective synthesis of several new air-stable zinc complexes based on N4– N,N-bis(2-pyridinecarboxamide)-1,2-benzene chelating ligands and their pyrazine-variation and their utilization with (NnBu)4I as co-catalyst in the coupling of epoxides with CO2 to form cyclic carbonates in good yields. The complexes were screened with cyclohexene oxide and propylene oxide as standard substrates. Additionally a broader catalytic screening involving several commercial available epoxides was performed with a selected catalyst. 2 Experimental 2.1 General procedure Whereas the synthesis of the ligands was carried out under normal atmosphere, the first step in the formation of the bpb–zinc-complexes has to be performed under controlled atmosphere (use of a pyrophoric organozinc compound as precursor). Once isolated the bpb–zinc-complexes are stable, building aquo–zinc-complexes under normal atmosphere, the water being directly coordinated at the metallic center as already found in earlier study dealing with N2O2–zinc complexes [19]. The traces of water that remains in the solid after the standard drying procedure (3–4h at 60°C under vacuum) represent no threat for the catalysts and the selectivity of the reaction (no detectable hydrolysis products). The chemicals were reagent grade, obtained from commercial sources such as Aldrich, abcr or Alfa Aesar and used without further purification. Cyclohexene oxide and propylene oxide were dried over CaH2 before their use. The ligand 1–4 and the complex 7 were synthesized according to literature procedures reported by Yamazaki and Higashi [20a], Barnes et al. [20b,21]. The 1H and 13C NMR spectra of catalysts and final products were recorded operating at 399.91 and 100.56MHz, respectively, by means of a Varian InovaUnity 400 spectrometer equipped with an Oxford Magnet (9.4T). Chemical shifts are reported in ppm, and J-coupling constants are expressed in Hz. The calibration was performed using the remaining signal of the non-deuteriated part of the solvent and the C–D characteristic coupling pattern of the deuteriated solvent in 13C, when necessary a supplementary calibration with TMS as internal standard has been done. When necessary short- and long range correlated 2D C,H- spectra (gHSQC and gHMBC, respectively) were recorded using standard pulse sequences with z-gradients, as provided by Varian with the VNMR 6.1C control and processing software. Mass spectra were measured with an Agilent 1100 MSD. Infrared spectra (KBr pellets) were recorded on a Varian 660-IR FT-IR spectrometer. Elementary analysis was measured with a CHN-Analyser Vario EL III of the company Elementar. 2.2 Synthesis of ligand 5 According to Yamazaki and Higashi [20a] and Barnes et al. The heating was performed with aluminum heating blocks controlled via the electronic thermometers of the magnetic stirrers. Each run listed in the “reactivity” Tables 1–4 was tested two times and if needed a third time; the reproducibility was high. The autoclaves were dried at 110°C under vacuum for two hours, cooled down and purged with argon before use. This procedure was once again applied for two hours at 60°C with the catalyst and the cocatalyst added to the autoclave. After cooling the autoclave to room temperature, the epoxide was injected under argon via one of the autoclave ports and the reaction mixture was pressurized with CO2. The experiments under a pressure of 2bar were performed by connecting the filled autoclave (10ml PO+catalyst) via a backpressure regulating valve to a CO2-cylinder during the whole progress of the reaction. After reaching the reaction temperature the pressure in the autoclave leveled off to a constant 2bar. After reaching the end of the test runs, autoclaves were cooled down to RT, slowly vented under stirring in a fume hood, opened and the remaining solution was collected with dichloromethane. After thorough drying, the solution was investigated via IR and 1H NMR-spectroscopy given that cyclic monomers and polycarbonates are easily differentiated via both spectroscopic methods. For instance, the stretching mode [22] of the CO bond in polycarbonates can be found around 1750cm−1 whereas the cyclic carbonates are typically found around 1800 (cis-cyclohexylene carbonate at 1802cm−1, trans-cyclohexylene carbonate at 1818cm−1 and propylene carbonate at 1800cm−1). In all the experiments only the cyclic monomer was obtained. Therefore, the effective cyclic carbonate amount was calculated by measuring the weight of the dried solution and subtracting the amount of co- and catalyst used. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthetic procedures The synthesis of the bpb–zinc complexes is shown in Scheme 2 . Although bispyridylamides are known for a long time and many metal complexes have been investigated, it is only recently that they have found more applications in the homogeneous catalysis [23]. The different bpb ligands (1-5) are obtained by condensation of 1,2-diaminobenzene with two equivalent of 2-pyridine-carboxylic acid or 2-pyrazine-carboxylic acid (ligand 5) in pyridine under activation with triphenyl phosphite according to Yamazaki and Higashi [20a] and Barnes et al. [20b]. Using the same method with 2-aminobenzylamine instead of ortho-phenylendiamine lead to ligand 6. The bpb–zinc complex 7 is already described by Chapman and Vagg [21], however it was synthesized according to the method used for the new bpb–zinc complexes 8–12 instead of using zinc chloride as starting material. The zinc complexes 7–12 can be isolated as orange–yellow amorphous powders with yields over 90% from the reaction of the different ligands with one equivalent of diethylzinc (1M solution in hexane) in dry THF at room temperature. The compounds once filtered, were thoroughly dried and firstly stored under argon. Interestingly the compounds form stable zinc–bpb aquo-complexes under standard atmosphere that can be stored for months without degradation. The compounds were characterized via NMR-spectroscopy, elemental analysis, IR-spectroscopy and MS–ESI. The analytic data obtained for the ligands 1–4 and the zinc complex 7 are in good agreement with the values found in the literature. Accordingly the analytics confirmed the structure expected for the new ligands and related complexes (5, 6 and 8–12). 3.2 Catalytic screening of the zinc bpb complexes in the coupling of epoxides with carbon dioxide Inspired by the promising results of the catalytic tests run with cobalt, chromium and iron bpb-complexes [17] we carried out similar tests with the bpb–zinc complexes alone and with addition of common co-catalysts, like e.g., tetrabutyl-ammonium iodide (TBAI). These catalytic tests were performed in 70ml SS316Ti autoclaves with a standard reaction time of 20h, at 80°C and 50bar CO2-pressure (for propylene oxide 35bar) under “solvent-free” conditions. The results are summarized in Table 1 for the screening with propylene oxide and in Table 3 for the screening with cyclohexene oxide. In both screenings different cocatalyst were utilized to find the best possible catalyst/cocatalyst combination for this reaction. Furthermore for propylene oxide more challenging reaction parameters (temp., p and reaction time) were investigated with the active combination complex 8/NBu4I (Table 2). Last but not least several commercially available epoxides were examined with the same catalyst combination and summarized in Table 4. Considering the screening with propylene oxide (Table 1) the results show that complex 8 (chosen as representative for the different zinc(bpb)-complexes) alone have no catalytic activity for the conversion of propylene oxide (Entry 1). TBAI or PPNCl [bis(triphenylphosphine iminium) chloride] used alone show only a minor activity (Entry 2 and 3: 4, respectively, 5% yield of PC) However, if a zinc(bpb)-complexes and an equivalent amount of a cocatalyst, like tetrabutylammonium-bromide (NBu4Br or TBAB in the text), are added together the formation of propylene carbonate is observed (Entry 5, 39% yield of PC). Expanding the range of the co-catalysts tested with complex 8 (Entry 4–9) showed that TBAI was the best cocatalyst for this system with a yield of 92% propylene carbonate for a catalyst/cocatalyst-concentration of 0.1mol%. In contrast to TBAI the use of 4-dimethyl-aminopyridine (DMAP) leads only to traces of PC (Entry 6), probably due to the formation of a stable (bpb)Zn-DMAP-complex as already suggested by the teams of Klaus et al. [24] or Rao et al. [25] for related systems. With regard to the nature of the halide ion used in the catalysis, the following activity trend appears: iodide (92% PC)>bromide (39% PC)>chloride (20% PC). This trend can be tentatively explained in two ways: interactions involving ammonium halides and epoxides, which play here also the part of the solvent, might increase the apparent nucleophilicity of the anion from chloride to iodide, whereas normally the reverse trend should prevail in aprotic polar solvents. On the other hand, the positive trend observed from chloride to iodide might be linked to the increasing ability of the leaving group to leave a reactive alkoxo-intermediate within the catalytic cycle, enabling so a ring closure and the generation of the cyclic carbonate (for mechanism vide infra, Scheme 3 ). This general “halide” trend is supported by DFT-calculations of Castro-Gomez et al. [26] for a zinc(salphen)-system, which show indisputably that for the formation of propylene carbonate a higher transition state has to be surmounted in case of TBAB than for TBAI. Taking into account the different chain lengths of the tetra-alkylammonium-cation (Entry 2 vs. Entry 8) a higher yield of PC was obtained for TBAI (Entry 2: 92% PC) than for tetraethylammoniumiodide (TEAI) (Entry 8: 69% PC). The reason for this observation is most likely found in the bigger steric repulsion that leads to an increase of the nucleophilicity of the halide [27]. The screening of the zinc(bpb)-complexes 7–12 at catalyst loadings of 0.1mol%, with addition of TBAI, showed that all complexes besides complex 10 (dimethyl substituents at the ortho-phenylene-linker) can produce PC in high yields, culminating at 92%. A clear gradation of the catalytic activity can be seen performing the tests with catalyst loadings at 0.05mol%. In this case complex 8 (chloro-substituents at the ortho-phenylene-linker) exhibits the highest yield with 88% of PC. This zinc-based system (Entry 8) delivered under the same experimental conditions a slightly higher TON for the PC-formation than the related cobalt(bpb) bromide-complex [17b] (TON:1620). The presence of electron-withdrawing or -donating substituents at the aromatic linker clearly influences the Lewis acidity of the metal center (e.g., entries 8,12 and 14, related to Entry 10). A related study performed by Ramidi et al. [28] with cobalt complexes based on N4-ligand confirms this, showing the favorable effect of electron-withdrawing groups. In that case the following reactivity trend, 2×Cl>1×NO2 >2×H>2×Me, was found for the synthesis of propylene carbonate. In our system the reactivity trend differs a bit, with the NO2-substituted ligand being less efficient than the unsubstituted one: 2×Cl>2×H>1×NO2 >>2×Me. The reason of the lower activity of the nitro derivative can be probably explicated by the dual role of the nitro group: it withdraws electron from the aromatic but can also act as a coordinating ligand per se. Such an interaction between metal center of one complex and a coordinating group of another complex competes with the coordination of the epoxide and hinders so the coupling reaction [29]. Complexes involving organic nitro compounds, albeit weak Lewis Bases, and strong Lewis Acids like Al3+ have been documented in the literature [30]. A similar situation is also thinkable with Zn2+, a borderline Lewis acid [31], which should lead, according to the HSAB principle, to an even better LA-LB match with a nitro group [32]. Interestingly modifications in other part of the backbone like the introduction of a methylene group (12, Entry 18) or the substitution of a carbon by a nitrogen in case of the pyrazinic acid derivative (11, Entry 16) have a negative, although narrow, impact on the efficiency of the catalysis. Motivated by the high activity of the combination complex 8/TBAI in the formation of propylene carbonate, we evaluated the usable temperature and pressure ranges with more challenging reaction parameters (Table 2). Reducing the reaction time from 20 to 5h (Entry 2, 75% PC) lead only to a slightly lowering of the yield, showing how effective this combination is. However, decreasing the temperature from 80 to 60°C (Entry 3) showed a distinct loss of activity (only 46% PC) whereas 40°C (Entry 4) provided only three percent of PC. Remarkably performing the reaction at 2bar CO2 and 60°C (Entry 5) leads to the formation of propylene carbonate in 32% yield. In contrast to the high catalytic activity of the combination 8/TBAI with propylene oxide, (Table 3, Entry 2), only six percent of cyclohexene carbonate (CHC) was obtained with cyclohexene oxide (CHO) used as substrate. Therefore following the same procedure as for propylene oxide, different common cocatalysts were examined with complex 8 to find the most suitable catalyst/cocatalyst combination for CHO (Entry 3–8). Only with TBAB (Entry 4, 10 % CHC) or bis(triphenylphosphine)iminium chloride (PPNCl, Entry 6, 9% CHC) a slight improvement is measured, with TBAB being the most effective cocatalyst. Consistent with the results found for propylene oxide, complex 8 alone displays no catalytic activity for cyclohexene oxide (Entry 1). Similarly to the screening run with PO, using the co-catalyst alone lead to traces of cyclohexene carbonate (Entry 2: 2% with TBAI). In reference to the tetrabutylammonium halides tested, bromide exhibits now the best reactivity (Entry 4, 10% CHC). This is related to the fact that bulky epoxides, like cyclohexene oxide, once “activated” by the metal center, can be easily opened only with a co-catalyst (halide anion) combining high nucleophilicity, good leaving group ability and “small size” [33]. Bromide seems to be the best compromise between chloride and iodide and represents the best match of these opposing influences. Considering now the CHO-screening of the different zinc(bpb)-complexes 7–12 with TBAB as co-catalyst and loadings of 0.2mol%, the general catalytic activity is poorer than in the case of PO (higher loadings and narrower yields). As mentioned for the role of the co-catalyst, the growing steric hindrance of the epoxide, from propylene to cyclohexene oxide, hinders most likely the coordination/activation to the metal center [14c]. Interestingly the electron-donating substituents (10, Entry 11) and the presence of a methylene linkage in the backbone complex (12, Entry 13) lead this time to a higher conversion of the epoxide whereas the electron-withdrawing substituents (8,9,11, Entries 4,10,12) and the substitution of a carbon by a nitrogen (12, Entry 13) lead to yields reaching at the very most 12%. The parent compound, with non-substituted phenylene linker yields 14% cyclic carbonate (7, Entry 9), the catalytic activity being a tad over that of the Zn–bpb’s with electro-withdrawing groups. To put things in perspective, the combination complex 10 / TBAB delivers a slightly higher yield of cyclohexene carbonate (34%) than the zinc(salphen) / TBAI-system of Whiteoak et al. [33] (29% CHC, at 80°C, 80bar, 2.5mol% catalyst loading and 3h) with a lower catalyst loading (0.2mol%) and CO2-pressure (50bar), but needs a longer reaction time (20h). In order to estimate the limits of these new zinc(bpb)-complexes, we undertook a broader catalytic screening with complex 8 and TBAB using a variety of commercially available epoxides (Table 4). The experiments were performed at 80°C, with a reaction time of 20h and a catalyst loading of 0.2mol%. The catalyst combination showed a high to moderate catalytic activity with yields up to 84% (Entry 1) forming selectively with each tested epoxide, except 2,3-dimethyl-2,3-epoxybutane, the cyclic carbonate. The highest yield of cyclic carbonate was reached with 3-phenoxy-propylene oxide (Entry 1, 84%), which can maybe explained by the ability of the electron-withdrawing phenoxy group to stabilize intermediates and consequently facilitates the intramolecular cyclization [34]. However, this assumption is somewhat undermined given that other monosubstituted epoxides displaying an electron-withdrawing group (Entries 3, 4 and 6) lead to lower yields than in the case of propylene oxide. As anticipated in the investigation with CHO, increasing the steric hindrance leads to lower conversions (Entry 6: 27% and Entry 7: 10%). 3.3 Mechanism proposal for the formation of cyclic carbonates with the zinc(bpb)-complexes As briefly mentioned in the introduction, a range of homogeneous catalytic systems based on zinc has been reported in the carbonate literature, the most investigated being the zinc phenoxides (O,O′) of Darensbourg and Holtcamp [35], the zinc beta-diiminates (N,N′) of Moore et al. [36], substituted amino bisphenoxides (N4O2) Kember et al. [16] and the zinc salphen (N2O2) of Kleij [14c,32]. Only one zinc-based system involving planar N4 ligand has been newly reported by the group around Ema et al. [37]. Drawing some parallels with these catalytic systems, and more particularly N4-system of Ema and Zn-salphens of Kleij, a general monometallic mechanism matching the findings of the study can be proposed (Scheme 3). Relying also on DFT-calculations performed with the zinc(salphen)/TBAX-system [38], it seems reasonable to consider a neutral mononuclear Zn(bpb)-complex with additional cocatalyst as starting point in the catalytic cycle. The first step to the formation of the cyclic carbonate involves the activation of the epoxide by coordination at the zinc complex. In the subsequent ring opening of the epoxide the ammonium halide co-catalyst comes into play. Through a nucleophilic attack of the halide ion a reactive metalalkoxide is formed. This reactive metalalkoxide bond is known to react easily with CO2 to form a metal–alkyl-carbonate. This intermediate can either form a polycarbonate through further alternating insertions of epoxide and carbon dioxide molecules or a cyclic monomer via intramolecular rearrangement and liberation of the leaving group. In our case, cyclic carbonates are selectively formed. Considering the ammonium cation of the cocatalyst, a role in the stabilization of the anionic specie forms cannot be completely excluded. A kinetic study is in progress to assess the kinetics of the reaction and get more insight into the mechanism. 4 Conclusions We have synthesized new zinc complexes based on a N,N-bis (2-pyridine-carboxamide)-1,2-benzene framework displaying either electron donating- or electron withdrawing substituents located at the diamino-spacer and also in some cases with modified backbones. These complexes were tested towards the coupling of different epoxides and carbon dioxide. The screening showed that the necessary addition of an ionic cocatalyst upgraded the zinc(bpb)-complexes to efficient catalysts, especially in case of PO, affording selectively cyclic carbonates even under mild reaction conditions and low catalyst loadings. In comparison to the related ionic [Co(bpbCl2)Br2][NEt4]-complex a higher catalytic activity for the selective formation of propylene carbonate is observed [17b]. Considering the tested ionic cocatalysts, the best results were achieved with tetrabutylammonium iodide for PO and tetrabutylammonium bromide for CHO. These results, in agreement with related literature data, lead us to propose a mechanism for this zinc(bpb)-catalyses coupling reaction. coredata.dc:description: In this contribution, we report the successful utilization of several zinc complexes based on the N4–N,N-bis(2-pyridinecarboxamide)-1,2-benzene chelating ligand (and some of its variations) as catalysts in the coupling of epoxides with carbon dioxide to afford cyclic carbonates in good yields. The complexes were tested with cyclohexene oxide and propylene oxide. A broader catalytic screening involving several commercial available epoxides was also carried out with a selected catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: New zinc catalysts based on easy-to-handle N4-chelating ligands for the coupling reaction of epoxides with CO2
